What is a trademark?.definition: A trademark is a any word, slogan, symbol, design, or combination of these that identifies the source of your goods and services and distinguishes them from the goods and services of another party
What is a trademark?.summed up: The only purpose of a trademark is to identify and distinguish
What is a trademark?.ps: A trademark can be a sound, a color, a smell, or anything that identifies and distinguishes your brand.
What is a trademark?.difference between trademark and a paten: Patents protect inventions, copyrights protect artistic and literary works. All three protect intellectual property
What is a trademark?.what's an example?: Samsung might use a patent to protect their phone technology, a trademark to protect their logo, and a copyright to protect their commercial for that phone.
What is a trademark?.domain names and business names: A domain name can function as a trademark, but domain registration is not federal trademark registration.  Likewise, a business name can function as a trademark, but registration of the business name does not automatically count as a trademark registration.

avoid likelihood of confusion - if your mark looks, sounds, or smells too much like another mark, the USPTO might interpret them as having similar meanings and creating similar commercial impressions. If consumers might believe the goods and services are coming from the same source, the trademark would not do its job of uniquely distinguishing and identifying your business
How to do it.trademark clearance search: trademark electronic search system, state trademark databases, business name databases, google
strength of the mark: how legally defensible is the mark?
generic marks are common, everyday names for goods and services, e.g. bike for a bicycle shop
descriptive marks are still very common, but are more like using creamy for a yogurt stand
fanciful marks are invented words without a dictionary definition, e.g. microsoft, cusinart
arbitrary marks are also strong, even though they have a dictionary definition, it's not associated with the goods or services, e.g. apple, blackberry, tesla, gap

PS - it's especially dangerous to use a generic or descriptive mark, because you cannot defend that consumers have come to understand that your mark means ONLY your particular goods and services - not just the goods and services from anyone e.g. Zipper, Escalator, YoYo. Fanciful marks are much easier to protect.
not likely to be confused with another
not deceptive, disparaging, or offensive (obviously there's some wiggle room here)
not a misspelling of descriptive or generic words
not a name or likeness of a person (who hasn't given consent)
not the title of a single book or movie
not an ornamental or decorative matter
In the end, it's your legal responsibility to police your mark - The USPTO won't enforce your rights to the trademark for you

Applying.important note: applying for registration correctly will save you thousands of dollars in fees. While I can share information with you here, I can't give legal advice or recommend an exact course of action - that's an attorney's job.  The big takeaway is that trademark applications are best filed in a way that will give you the most flexibility in the future as your brand evolves.
Factors affecting fees: number of goods and services classes - separate fees
which form you use - TEAS Regular ($400), TEAS Plus ($200 + specific requirements), TEAS RF ($275 + specific requirements)
basis for filing - statement of use ($100 per class)
$125 registration maintenance fee after 5 years of use
$425 registration renewal fee after 9 years of use
Types of mark 'drawings': Standard character mark is just the plain text name of your brand. I grants protection to the wording itself, meaning you can change how you display the wording later, without having to re-file.
Special form marks include stylized wordmarks and logo designs
Being specific with the mark: The submitted image must contain the whole mark, with nothing cut off
The description must be clear and precise (e.g. 'the mark consists of the wording 'Braden East Studio' in a stylized manner')
To claim your colors, say something like 'The colors Blue and Black are claimed as a feature of the mark'

The most flexible way would be to submit the mark in black and white - indicating that no colors are claimed. This way, if you do decide to change colors later, your trademark is still legally protectable and doesn't need a new registration filed.
